facts.text: Will was executed on February 10, 1906 by Kunhan Kaimal, Kesavan Kaimal, and Theyi Amma.

anchor.surface_text: will dated February 10, 1906, jointly by Kunhan Kaimal, son of Karayamvattath Katbayakkal Kunhu Kutti Amma, Kesavan Kaimal, son of Theyi Amma and Theyi Amma, daughter of Nani Amma of Etathiruthi amsom and Etamuttan desom in Ponnani Taluk.

facts.text: Theyi Amma died first among the three testators.

anchor.surface_text: of the three testators, Theyi Amma died first-the exact date of her death does number appear and is number very material-

facts.text: Kunhan Kaimal died sometime in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: and Kunhan Kaimal died thereafter sometime in 1930.

facts.text: Kesavan Kaimal conveyed seven items of properties on October 14, 1938 to Sankarankutti Kaimal, of which three belonged to Kunhan Kaimal.

anchor.surface_text: he conveyed on October 14,1938, seven items of properties, of which three belonged to Kunhan Kaimal, to one Sankarankutti Kaimal

facts.text: Kesavan Kaimal conveyed another three items of properties belonging to Kunhan Kaimal on October 16, 1944 to Kalyani and Vijayan.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 16, 1944, another three items of properties which belonged to Kunhan Kaimal, to Kalyani and Vijayan.

facts.text: Legatees under the 1906 will instituted O.S. No. 131 of 1945 in District Munsif, Chowghat for possession of three items after redeeming mortgage for Rs. 100 dated February 3, 1901.

anchor.surface_text: The legatees under the will dated February 10, 1906, instituted O. S. No. 131 of 1945 in the Court of the District Munsif, Chowghat... for recovery of possession of three items of properties which had belonged to Kunhan Kaimal after redeeming a mortgage for Rs. 100 created over those properties on February 3, 1901.

facts.text: Plaintiffs in O.S. 131/1945 claimed entitlement to properties on death of Kunhan Kaimal in 1930 as legatees under the will.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claimed that on the death of Kunhan Kaimal in 1930 they had become entitled to those properties as legatees under the will.

facts.text: In O.S. 131/1945, Defendants 1 to 3 were mortgagees, Defendant 6 was Kesavan Kaimal, Defendants 4 and 5 were transferees under deed dated October 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 1 to 3 represented the mortgagees. Defendant 6 was Kesavan Kaimal, and defendants 4 and 5 were brought on record as persons claiming to be entitled to the suit properties under a deed of transfer by defendant 6, dated October 16, 1944.

facts.text: Defendants in O.S. 131/1945 contested claiming properties of Kunhan Kaimal survived to Kesavan Kaimal on his death in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 4 to 6 contested the suit, and pleaded that on a proper construction of the will, the properties of Kunhan Kaimal survived to Kesavan Kaimal on the death of the former in 1930, and that the plaintiffs got number title to them.

facts.text: District Munsif, Chowghat decreed O.S. 131/1945 in favor of plaintiffs on October 9, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment and decree dated October 9, 1945, and June 29, 1946, respectively of the Court of Districts Munsif, Chowghat, in S. Nos. 131 and 158 of 1945.

arguments.claim: Word 'will' has well-understood meaning as disposition taking effect on death

anchor.surface_text: The word will is widely known and used, and it has a well- understood significance as meaning a disposition which is to take effect on the death of a person.

holdings.text: The will dated February 10, 1906 did not operate to vest all properties in the three testators as joint owners with survivorship to Kesavan Kaimal.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in these appeals is whether under the will all the three testators became joint owners of all the properties on which it operated. After hearing the question fully argued, we have come to the conclusion that that is not the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court contra cannot be supported.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction shows no divestment of individual ownership, clause 3 permits alienation by any testator, unstamped document cannot effect inter vivos transfer, future properties cannot be disposed in praesenti.

holdings.text: Kesavan Kaimal did not become entitled under the will to the properties of Kunhan Kaimal; those properties vested in the legatees on Kunhan Kaimal's death.

anchor.surface_text: The point for determination in these two appeals is whether one Kesavan Kaimal who was one of three executants of a will dated February 10, 1906, became entitled under that will to the properties, which are the subject-matter of these appeals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will operates as testamentary disposition separately for each testator's properties upon their death, no inter se rights among testators.

holdings.text: The document is a testamentary disposition taking effect on death, not an inter vivos transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The word will is widely known and used, and it has a well- understood significance as meaning a disposition which is to take effect on the death of a person. The executants of the will could not have therefore intended that it should operate inter ViVOs. Moreover, if the document was intended to take effect as a present disposition, it should have to be stamped under the provisions of the Stamp Act, but the will is an unstamped document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning of 'will'; unstamped status precludes inter vivos operation; clause affirming control till death.

holdings.text: There are no words in the will divesting testators of individual ownership and vesting jointly.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the recitals in the will, there are no words by which the executants thereof divest themselves of their individual ownership and vest it in themselves jointly.

holdings.text: Clause 3 of the will conclusively shows properties not held jointly as testators could alienate jointly or severally till death.

anchor.surface_text: The matter appears to us to be concluded beyond all doubt by the terms of clause 3, which provides that the testators could alienate the properties jointly or severally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express permission for individual alienation incompatible with joint tenancy survivorship.

holdings.text: Evidence of subsequent conduct inadmissible to interpret clear and unambiguous will.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever value one might attach to the above considerations if there was any doubt or uncertainty as to the meaning of the will, when once it is held that the language thereof is clear and unambiguous, evidence of the subsequent conduct of the parties cannot be admitted for the purpose of limiting or controlling its meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will's language clear; subsequent acts cannot alter plain meaning.

holdings.text: The will cannot be construed as a mutual will as testators did not confer reciprocal benefits on each other.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutual wills require testators to be legatees reciprocally; here legatees are distinct.

holdings.text: The will is a joint will operating as the separate will of each testator upon their death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by Halsbury and Jarman on Wills; operates separately on each death disposing of separate property.

precedents.cited_proposition: Joint wills made by multiple testators in a single document can be given effect, operating as the individual will of each testator upon their death, admitting to probate the property of each.

anchor.surface_text: The word will is widely known and used, and it has a well- understood significance as meaning a disposition which is to take effect on the death of a person. The executants of the will could not have therefore intended that it should operate inter ViVOs. Moreover, if the document was intended to take effect as a present disposition, it should have to be stamped under the provisions of the Stamp Act, but the will is an unstamped document.
After hearing the question fully argued, we have come to the conclusion that that is not the effect of the will, and that the judgment of the High Court contra cannot be supported.
